review.title: "Pale as death" or "p\^ale comme la mort" : Frozen similes used as literary clich\'es
review.abstract: The present study is focused on the automatic identification and description of frozen similes in British and French novels written between the 19 th century and the beginning of the 20 th century. Two main patterns of frozen similes were considered: adjectival ground + simile marker + nominal vehicle (e.g. happy as a lark) and eventuality + simile marker + nominal vehicle (e.g. sleep like a top). All potential similes and their components were first extracted using a rule-based algorithm. Then, frozen similes were identified based on reference lists of existing similes and semantic distance between the tenor and the vehicle. The results obtained tend to confirm the fact that frozen similes are not used haphazardly in literary texts. In addition, contrary to how they are often presented, frozen similes often go beyond the ground or the eventuality and the vehicle to also include the tenor.

metadata.title: “Pale as death” or “pâle comme la mort”: Frozen similes used as literary clichés

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Although this is mainly a matter of creative writing and deviation, it can be said that clichés can be used for stylistic effects (Amossy & Herschberg-Perrot, 1997).According to Abrams, a cliché can be defined that attracts the attention of the author and that remains as it is.

sections.heading: 2. COMPUTATIONAL APPROACHES TO SIMILE IDENTIFICATION
sections.text: In rhetoric, a parable such as (3) "This girl is graceful as a lily" is composed chiefly of the following components: - a tenor or an object of comparison; - a tertium comparationis or ground: the adjective or verb that denotes the property shared by the units compared; - a vehicle that refers to the term against which the tenor is evaluated (Fishelov, 1993). In addition to these components, Hanks (2012) also distinguishes contingency, the main verb on which equilibrium is built. As far as French is concerned, the comparison clause with a verb and an adjective ellipsis is the form "A est B comme C," which is generally considered a prototypical form of equilibrium and is discussed at length in terms of rhetoric in relation to metaphors (Cohen, 1968).

sections.heading: 3. PROPOSED METHOD
sections.text: This study is limited to nominal comparisons of the form of adjective ground + similarity marker + nominal vehicle (e.g. cunning as a fox) and contingency + similarity marker + nominal vehicle (e.g. crying like a baby). Since similarity or dissimilarity is derived primarily from meaning, as opposed to previous work on clichés (Bolshakov, 2003), not only traditional markers have been included, but also other markers that can be combined with these two predefined similarity patterns. Table 1 lists all selected markers and their corresponding similarity structures. The proposed approach to recognizing frozen similarities in literary texts can be divided into two main parts: - extraction and degradation of similarities, comparisons and pseudo-comparisons; - filtering of all extracted elements based on their idiomaticity and the semantic distance between vehicle and tenor.

sections.heading: 3.1. The simile extraction and mining module
sections.text: The various steps performed in this section are derived from the rules-based algorithm presented in Mpouli and Ganascia (2015). The extraction and mining phase includes various pre-processing tasks, the extraction of seedlings, and finally the identification of the components of each extracted simulation candidate. Pre-processing tasks include tokenization, syntactical decoupling, and sentence segmentation. The first three tasks are performed with TreeTagger (Schmid 1994), a freely available multilingual tokenist, part of the speech tagger, and chunker1. The sentence boundaries defined by TreeTagger form the first basis for sentence segmentation, and are corrected with specific rules when a question or exclamation mark is not followed by a capital.

sections.heading: 3.2. Filtering of frozen similes
sections.text: To detect frozen comparisons, all soil / contingency + vehicle pairs were first compared with a list of frozen comparisons of the corresponding language compiled from various sources such as Nicolas Cazelles "Les Comparaisons du français (1996) or Michel Parmentier's Dictionnaire français / anglais des comparaisons (2002). However, since the reference lists of frozen comparisons were largely based on sources that were not up to date with the novels of the Corpus and were by no means comprehensive, frequency and semantic distance were used to filter out frozen comparisons between the remaining soil / contingency + vehicle pairs. All soil / contingency + vehicle pairs that appeared at least five times in novels by different authors were selected in this way. Then, the semantic distance between tenor and vehicle was evaluated in each sentence. If both the tenor and the vehicle were nouns, their semantic categories were classified from two machine-readable Le Contenté categories (French word identification), each of which are classified in three separate categories.

sections.heading: 4. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4. 1. Presentation of the corpus
sections.text: The two corpus used in this experiment were created using digital versions of literary texts in the public domain, collected mainly from the Project Gutenberg website2 and the Bibliothèque électronique du Québec3 for British and French novels, respectively. Most novels included in the corpus were written in the 19th century to ensure linguistic homogeneity, and because in that century the 2 www.gutenberg.org 3 beq.ebooksgratuits.com novel asserted itself as the dominant literary genre. Furthermore, a ratio of at least 3 novels per author was observed and the novels were not limited to a particular literary genre, making it possible to create a corpus of 1191 British novels written by 62 authors and a corpus of 746 French novels written by 57 writers.

sections.heading: 4.2. Description of detected frozen similes
sections.text: The relatively small number of total occurrences of the above mentioned persons in each language (listed in Table 3) seems to confirm the fact that clichés in general and frozen similarities in particular are anything but common in literary texts. Furthermore, French writers are more inclined to use frozen similarities than British ones. A noteworthy result of this study is the fact that the same parable (pale + marker + death and pale + marker + mort) is most commonly used in both languages. This parable is also interesting from a stylistic point of view, as it attributes a human characteristic to an abstract entity. In fact, "pale" and its synonym, "white," appear; in most cases, "death" is used in three of the highest category of frozen English similarities.

sections.heading: 5. CONCLUSION
sections.text: The aim of this work was to examine frozen literary comparisons in a corpus of novels in English and French. If most of the extraction of comparisons and their components takes place automatically, the recognition of frozen comparisons is still based in part on human knowledge. In this respect, it seems to be necessary for future work to first decipher the tenor or the vehicle in order to directly find its semantic category. Since this study is mainly focused on a stylistic description of comparisons, it would be a different perspective to add information about the literary cliché of a particular comparison to a comparison in order to shed new light on the perception and interpretation of frozen comparisons in literature as a whole.
